posts.name: Corbin Kuster
posts.cooked: The feature script I have for timing belts is good for modeling a belt or chain, but I’m looking for something better for when it’s time to 3D print the belts. First, the one I have requires at least 2 pulley references and their diameters to calculate the size of the belt. I want to be able to just tell it how many teeth I want and have it generate a circular model of the belt. Does anyone have recommendations for a different tool/feature script? With that, does it really matter if the belt is printed in a circle versus in a pattern (like how it would look when installed)? The one I’ve already printed didn’t seem to hang up on any curves once it broke in, but I feel like it would make sense for it to run better if it were printed in a circle. Thanks

posts.name: Clay
posts.cooked:
I have to recommend you don’t print belts. Real belts undergo a lot of stress, and are typically reinforced with some kind of fiber (anything from natural fibers all the way up to steel) that makes them stronger, and keeps them from stretching.  You’re not going to get a belt that resists stretching and lasts through a competition (if at all) by 3D printing it from TPU.  It’s just not made for it, and I think you’re probably going to be disappointed in the results. It’s worth the money to buy the belts you need.  Even knockoff cheapo belts will probably perform better than 3D printed belts.  I just don’t think it’s a wise use of 3D printed materials.

Maybe someone can prove me wrong, but I wouldn’t gamble on it for something so critical.

posts.name: Corbin Kuster
posts.cooked: I agree- for something critical? This is the wrong way to go. But for a scrapped together mechanism that we’re adding in our 10 day turnaround between events that will hardly be a hinderance if it fails, I think it’s an acceptable application. It’s a minimal force, at little tension, and very little of our performance rides on it

posts.name: Erik Boyle
posts.cooked:
We’re having a lot of success printing belts out of 95A TPU. Granted they are more fragile than the real things, but we understood that going in. Still, we have several on our robot and went through an entire competition with no failures other than one small nick, which we patched up with a soldering iron and a dab of epoxy during the playoffs. We print them with a thickness of 2.4 mm from root to back, which is a bit thicker than the standard profile. If you’re worried about strength, you can print your own pulleys as well and increase the width for some extra safety factor.

Because of the stretch of the TPU, we undersize the tooth count by 5% (yes, you read that right, 5 whole percent). It can make them run slightly rough on the pulleys because the belt pitch doesn’t match the pulley pitch exactly after stretching. In the future, I’d like to investigate scaling down the pitch and maintaining the tooth count instead, but it hasn’t been a priority.

The main reason we got so into printing belts was the ability to add custom features to the surface. We prototyped multiple iterations of lugs for coral conveyance before eventually using this one in our first event. We may make another revision before our next event.

1000004100 1920×3413 846 KB

1000004100 1920×3413 846 KB

1000004100 1920×3413 846 KB

Now, the dirty little secret. This part studio isn’t actually an HTD profile —we copied it from elsewhere and modified it further. It was originally based on a GT2 profile with deepened teeth. We scaled it up to 5 mm pitch to run it with HTD pulleys (we also print pulleys with deepened teeth). I would contend that if the difference between the tooth shapes, after accounting for printing tolerance, is a deal breaker for your application, it probably isn’t the right application for a printed belt.

That said, I would recommend it to anyone with a little bit of patience to dial in their prints.

A few tips:

TPU is stringyyyyy Dry dry dry your TPU. All the time. Lower temperatures and slower speeds can help I also have my printer set to retract the filament 1 mm, Z hop 1 mm, and to avoid crossing walls on travel, all of which seem to make a difference

Dry dry dry your TPU. All the time.

Lower temperatures and slower speeds can help

I also have my printer set to retract the filament 1 mm, Z hop 1 mm, and to avoid crossing walls on travel, all of which seem to make a difference

Print with outer/inner wall order (the opposite of what many slicers default to) Printing inner walls first can result in the printer starting by laying down individual tiny blobs for the center of each tooth, which tend to catch on each other or on strings from the extruder and create voids in the teeth

Printing inner walls first can result in the printer starting by laying down individual tiny blobs for the center of each tooth, which tend to catch on each other or on strings from the extruder and create voids in the teeth

Obviously, print solid wall all the way through the belt so the entire volume is made of concentric loops.

However much you try, be prepared to post-process your belts with a pair of tweezers to get the pesky strings off

At a minimum, it’s great for prototyping to be able to throw something together without regard for what belts you have in stock. With some effort, it’s turned into a whole new dimension in our design space that we didn’t know we could explore, which is what excites me most.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Somewhere between Thunderstruck and Country Roads

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked: But belts are cheap and easy to get quickly, as long as you use the right supplier. No idea why you’d bother to print them when you’ll spend almost as much for the TPU and get a vastly inferior product. I’d suggest looking at V-Belt Guys , who have pretty much any HTD (i.e., 5mm pitch) belt you could ask for. To find the tooth count you need, just divide the length of the belt (which is in mm) by 5. For instance, a standard 50 tooth HTD belt used in FIRST would have the part number 250-5m-09, that is 250mm long, 5mm pitch, and 9mm wide. Once you have the hang of their system, it’s easy to find them. That 50 tooth belt, by the way, is currently priced at $2.18. They ship fast and have pretty much every size you could every want, including all those odd sizes that the regular robotics suppliers don’t have.

link_counts.title: Precision Timing Belts for Sale - XL, MXL, & More | V-Belt Guys

posts.name: Corbin Kuster
posts.cooked: Scenario: 43-tooth belt works, but we want to try 42-tooth. So hypothetically, I go to VBelt Guys and buy a belt for $3.16, then pay $40 to have it overnighted so we can try it tomorrow. That’s already the cost of an entire spool of TPU. We also have an abundance of TPU 95A available as one of our mentors has a shop that accidentally made a bulk order of it, and they use very little. Instead, I would like to print a belt in 45 minutes and have it in my hands before the end of the meeting. I understand the downsides of TPU in comparison to a proper belt, and have determined that our decision is justified and adequate. I appreciate everyone’s concerns for the longevity, it’s not a great permanent solution, but whether or not I should use TPU was not my question…

posts.name: Bill Van Loo (FRC 1076, FTC25906)
posts.cooked:
Ekcrbe:

With some effort, it’s turned into a whole new dimension in our design space that we didn’t know we could explore, which is what excites me most.

This is such a great way to state this, and it’s an approach that I seek to inspire in my team: what can we do with what we already have, especially things that we didn’t know we could do?

604’s “ Scrappy not Crappy ” has been a big influence here along those lines. We don’t have a great way to fixture tubing on our Shapeoko CNC, but we do have a 3D printer and drill press/cordless drills. Let’s 3D print a drill jig/guide instead that helps students put holes exactly where we want them!

posts.name: Jaco Xia
posts.cooked:
Here is something I made a while back with options for double sided belt You have to multiply the amount of teeth by the pitch (for HTD the pitch is 5mm) to get the belt length. I made this a while ago but I don’t know why I didn’t have belt teeth as the input instead. It’s whatever though.

Alternatively, you can also use this featurescript to get a weirder shape for longer belts

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked: Okay, so print the belt for testing for size tomorrow and order the belt but just shipped flat rate. It would still get there in time to put on for your competition and you’d only be dropping about $10 on it. That’s way less than a spool of TPU. You get the best of both worlds and don’t end up reprinting that belt over and over as it inevitably breaks (and we all know that it’s going to break at the worst possible moment, because that’s just the way these things go.)

posts.name: Erik Boyle
posts.cooked:
Just for posterity, that 95T belt I shared took (I believe) 28 g of filament. I’ll call it 30 g after purging etc. That means I can get 33 belts out of a 1 kg spool that costs $28, for a unit cost of about $0.85 (plus electricity, sure).

Don’t print belts just to save money—obviously this isn’t the place to scrimp in critical applications. But on the other hand, claiming that it’s basically the same price plus extra effort for no benefit isn’t fair either.

Edit: Let me make another point. How many of you have used polycord or polybelt on your robot in the past? Were you unwilling to take the risk of using such a fragile component? Or did you understand the trade-offs and make a design decision? This is the same thing, with the added improvements that printed timing belts actually have teeth instead of relying entirely on friction to transfer torque and don’t have the inbuilt weak point of a weld joint. In particular, if you could eliminate that second point, how scared would you be of using weldless polycord? How often have you broken one not at the joint, but through the bulk medium?

Don’t use it to lift your elevator. Duh. But the are plenty of applications where printed belts can do just fine for you. I promise.

I appreciate everyone’s concerns for the longevity, it’s not a great permanent solution, but whether or not I should use TPU was not my question…

posts.name: Red Raider Admin
posts.cooked: We used AMS based TPU from Bambu Labs for testing belts.  When we were happy with them, we ordered the real belts.  We found that they got fragile the more you ran them and started to have some moving past their Yield strength, which is why you do prefer to use a normal belt to handle the stress and strain that the belts are under in the system.  3D Printed Belts = Great Prototyping but not for permanent solutions.  Until they make something like a TPU with carbon fiber embedded as continuous strand, I don’t think it will be viable.  Something like this could be done ( Buy TPU CF )  Never tried it but could be some fun off season experimenting.   It has anti-static properties as well.

posts.name: Corbin Kuster
posts.cooked: That’s the position we are in. I printed them with Bambu’s 95A and figured out how well we liked the added mechanism. We will likely make a purchase of actual belts now that we know we want to keep the mechanism, make no modifications in belt or pulley size, and have gained experience with printing belts

posts.name: Red Raider Admin
posts.cooked: We do print our pulleys though, so we use the PA-12 CF and anneal it at 80C for about 8 hours before using them.  Works really well and they are super light.

posts.name: Corbin Kuster
posts.cooked: I’ve had good luck with PETG. We especially like the way the races crack out in pieces upon impact instead of coming completely removed from the pulley like an aluminum one. Although my preference is ABS over PETG, PETG is easier to make replacements for at comp. Haven’t had the opportunity to venture into PA quite yet

posts.name: Red Raider Admin
posts.cooked: We’ve had a few “melt” on us due to overloading but that was driver error and was much easier to replace than the belts. Never had any break due to collision though.
